text: Your bank emails you saying 'URGENT: Your account is locked! Click here to verify now.'
explanation: Legit banks rarely ask you to click urgent links — check official site directly.

text: Your friend messages you on WhatsApp with a link to funny cat videos hosted on YouTube.
explanation: This is a normal safe link from a friend, nothing suspicious here.

text: You receive an email with poor grammar asking for your password to 'avoid account suspension.'
explanation: Never share passwords via email — this is a phishing classic.

text: An online shop sends you a receipt for something you never bought, with a link to 'cancel order.'
explanation: Fake receipts try to scare you into clicking malicious links.

text: Your company IT sends a scheduled notice: 'Servers will be down for maintenance on Saturday.'
explanation: Routine notifications are fine — no urgent clicks required.

text: An email claims you won a lottery you never entered and asks for personal info to claim prize.
explanation: Classic scam — if you didn’t enter, you didn’t win.

text: Your password manager app notifies you of a data breach and recommends you change your password.
explanation: Legitimate security apps do send these alerts — take action.

text: An SMS says: 'Your package is held at customs. Pay $5 fee here: shady-link.biz'.
explanation: Delivery companies use official sites, not random short links.

text: You get an email from GitHub about a login from a new device with location details.
explanation: This is a real security notification, but double-check the sender domain.

text: A 'tech support' popup tells you your computer is infected and shows a phone number to call.
explanation: Fake support scams try to scare you — never call those numbers.
